LG.L: HOW goes it my HAMLET, thou prince of the bridle?
Who to work art so ready, tho' I am oft idle—
In thy walk, trot, or gallop, when didst thou need whipping?
Or a spur to thy side, who art never caught tripping?
Does Bob always dress thee well, comb thee, and curry?
I mean as he ought to do, not in a hurry;
Does he act as a friend to thee, not as a stranger?
Is there hay in thy rack, and good oats in thy manger?
With plenty of straw does he make up thy bed?
As oft as is proper to water art led?
That he ever has done so, Bob makes it his boast;
I'm inclin'd to believe him for HAMLET's no ghost.
Good fare thou shalt have, and kind usage besides,
Since much I do owe thee for all my sweet rides.
With health, noble HAMLET, instruction I've caught,
Which thou from thy Master of old must have brought;
He gave me a treasure I could not withstand,
And nought but what's good ever came from his hand;
His manners so gentle, his heart free from blame,
Thy master of old is a WOLFF a GEORGE WOLFT, Esq the Danish Consul, who gave the Horse. but in name.
My HAMLET, I tell thee, with thanks for thy pains,
'Tis thou may'st be trusted, not I, with the reins;
Tho' I bridle thy tongue, yet I fear 'twill be shown
There still is much need of well curbing my own.
The loss of thine eye, tho' a blemish it be,
Gives also, good HAMLET, instruction to me;
And hints to all those, who that blemish deride,
That tho' they have two eyes, they have a blind side.
Thro' the journey of life let us keep the right road,
Tho' heavy our burthen, support well the load;
Up-hill work we shall have, and rough ways we shall find,
But, still jogging on, we shall leave them behind.
Yet think not, brave HAMLET, the rest of thy days
(With merit entitled to much better lays)
Shall be spent in hard work; or that in thy old age
Thou shalt gallop and trot, or shalt pant thro' a stage;
Faithful servants, like thee, should find rest at the last,
Not die in the harness, when labour is past;
A friend thou hast, HAMLET, a judge of true merit,
Who often hath prais'd both thy beauty and spirit;
Thy good points and temper to CRICKITT b C. ALEXANDER CRICKITT, Esq M. P. of Smyth's Hall, Essex. are known
His notice is gain'd, and his care will be shown—
SMYTH'S HALL will receive thee, whenever we part,
Those lovely rich meadows will cheer thy old heart;
From whip and spur free, thou shalt roll in fine clover,
Rejoicing, good HAMLET, thy labour is over—
Whilst I, not ambitious, nor greedy of pelf,
Some quiet retreat shall seek out for myself.

DIV1.HEAD: On STELLA's seizing a Pair of ANGOLA GLOVES.

LG.L: DEAR STELLA once was wond'rous cold,
Her lovely little hand was shiv'ring;
Out Cupid flew, for Love is bold,
With Gloves quite warm, for he was quiv'ring;
Angola's stripes, which caught her eyes,
Such fleecy comfort could bestow,
She sciz'd at once the friendly prize,
And, cherish'd thus, began to glow.—
Thus STELLA, of the world the pride,
Was favour'd by the Gods above,
While Love, exulting, archly cry'd,
"STELLA and I are Hand and Glove!"

DIV1.HEAD: THE EXCUSE. On a beautiful YOUNG LADY's being in Bed at ten o'clock on a fine Summer's Morning.

LG.L: SHOULD BELLA every morning rise
Early to greet the eastern sun,
The lustre of her brilliant eyes
Might check the course he meant to run:
The soaring Lark, with warbling throat,
No longer would his mate rejoice,
But own her far superior note,
And drop at her melodious voice:
The Lily and the blushing Rose
At BELLA's charms would hide their head,
And their bright hues no more disclose,
But wish her still to keep her bed:
Oh then, fair ISABEL, indulge,
While Nature's works we all revere,
I this plain truth will now divulge—

L.HI: Thy beauty might too oft appear.

DIV1.HEAD: TO STELLA, With a NECKLACE, on which was the Letter T, the Initial of the Author's Name.

LG.L: WHILE on her neck, with careless ease,
Shall dwell this happy Chain,
Where monarchs, oh, 'twould monarchs please,
May sigh to rest in vain;
Then I too that proud honour share,
And cry in warmest glee,
If 'tis not Love that plac'd me there,
'Tis Friendship to a T.
But Love and Friendship now may sport,
Since Age thus whispers Youth,
"As your Esteem is all I court,
"I say that T is Truth."
Oh then what happiness I gain,
And real joy to think,
While purest FRIENDSHIP forms the Chain,
TRUTH rivets every Link.

DIV1.HEAD: TO JENS WOLFF, ESQ SHERWOOD HOUSE, With a Collar of CANTERBURY Brawn.

LG.L: THAT "Wine does wonders," we are told,
And why not Brawn too I would ask?
It makes us BRAWNY, tho' we're old,
Can more be done by any flask?
Wine makes us choleric or crusty,
And Brawn too rises into COLLAR;
If 'tis right Oxford, never musty—
Yet Canterbury beats it hollow.
But shall we married men dare venture
To shew our wit about the Brawn?
If Wit, for once, our heads should enter,
We must take care, Sir, of the Horn.
But, who's afraid?—Serve up the Brawn—
With mustard keen enrich your plate,
Nor oil and vinegar e'er scorn,
And glib it down at any rate.
Then shiver, souse, and glib again,
Till the fill'd stomach crave no more;
And Prudence, ever in our train,
Cries "TO a WOLFF be not a BOAR."
This but a luncheon will afford
To Sherwood's gay and charming party;
While Christmas greets the festive board,
Where Beauty reigns with Friendship hearty.
Let Beauty reign with lovely smiles,
Let Friendship cheer, and Wit delight,
Let Love, which every care beguiles,
Long hail the day, and bless the night.

DIV1.HEAD: On a YOUNG LADY's having had her Tooth drawn.

LG.L: SHALL Pain dare to dwell in a mouth that's so sweet,
Which Friendship and Love can impart!
The Traitor, in irons, shall fall at her feet,
While Grief I'd expell from her heart;
Let Pain then be banish'd for Joy in its stead,
As far as the North from the South;
This Tooth was the only bad thing in her head,
Or that ever came out of her mouth.

DIV1.HEAD: THE BEEF-STEAK.
DIV1.L: YOU may talk of your Pontacs, or Dollys, or tavern,
For Sans Souci comfort they're dull as a cavern.—
If a tender Beef-Steak for your Saturday's dinner,
Not thick from the rump, and which should not be thinner;
If a snug little parlour-like house-keeper's store-room,
With a pleasant quartetto, who would not wish more room;
If done to a turn, hissing hot on your plate,
From off the groov'd gridiron never to wait;
If the shredded Chalotte shall e'en add to the goût,
While another good slice, with fine fat, is in view;
If a friend at your elbow points out a nice bit,
Pouring on it the gravy your palate to hit;
If a joke, or a banter, or whimsical pun,
Seems to shew with Beef-Steak you may nearly have done;
If a tankard of porter, Thrale's foaming Entire,
Goes down with a smack, and fresh glee shall inspire;
If these shall delight, and a bottle of port,
To fill to a Friend, or the Fair whom you court;
You are now on the spot, with true glee, to partake,
Enjoy, while you can then, the friendly Beef-Steak.

LG.L: TO Ladies shew a double face!
To Beauty use a double Tongue!
Unless I fairly state the case,
You'll, surely, think it very wrong—
If, then, fond Love should find relief,
Or, you, unkind, my hope destroy;
One Face will serve to shew my Grief,
The other to express my Joy.

DIV1.HEAD: BACCHUS DRINKING ARIADNE.
DIV1.L:
HER Temper is Burgundy,
The gay, serene, good-natur'd Burgundy. ARMSTRONG. Wit is Champaign,
Her Judgment sound Port, and her Spirits right Cane,
Her Voice is Canary, her Lips, with a smack,
I freely pronounce to be sweeter than Sack;
As my Wine in rich Goblets, I copiously pour,
It sparkles indeed, but her Eyes sparkle more;
What Wine shall I drink then? What Hogshead shall broach?
A Hogshead won't do, though as sound as a Roach;
For, in truth, I so love, and so highly respect her,
Her Health I will drink in an Ocean—of Nectar.

DIV1.HEAD: Of what Shape do you fancy a KISS?

LG.L: "SAY, is it Round? or Oval? Square?
"Or, is the line of Beauty there?"—
A Globe its Figure may confess,
Tho' Worlds its sweetness can't express—
A Kiss will instant Joy impart,
And prove the feelings of the Heart—
With Kate, 'tis kind; with Chloe coy,
With Bella bliss, with Julia joy;
With ev'ry Nymph some charm is given,
But with my CAROLINE—'tis Heaven!
—"Yet wherefore SPHERICAL?" you'll say;
—I wish a Kiss, a ROUNDELAY.

DIV1.HEAD: On the DEATH of TOM CHELSEA, a Waterman.

LG.L: TOM'S life, like the current, fast glided away,
And his tide, like old Time, for no mortal would stay;
His years, sixty-eight, had yet surely been more,
If that old pilot, Death, had not put in his oar.
By stars and by garters the nobles we note;
The marks of Tom's honours—his badge and his coat;
At the flood we to Fame and to Fortune may ride,
His tokens of merit were gain'd against tide;
Though for feats, or for tournaments, Tom was not built,
His wherry could prove him adroit at a tilt;
Some call'd him inconstant—his wife did not care,
And was always well pleas'd when he met with a fare;
He trimm'd well his boat—and he never was dull,
And if not the first wit, 'twas no fault of his scull;
Old Charon rejoic'd when he came to the shores,
Seiz'd Tom with his boat-hook, and cried out, Oars! Oars!
SINCE no fair lady enters here,
For once I'll venture to appear;
Too well I know, by having try'd her,
A lady can't endure a Spider.
I have indeed one chance to win her,
By changing to a golden spinner.—
At court, perhaps you've often seen,
A monarch, or a splendid queen,
Encircled with the gay and great,
And all the pomp of royal state—
Much greater sure it must be own'd
Than such a prince am I enthron'd,
For seated in my circled centre,
No giddy fly will dare to enter:
If once within thy silken court,
I squeeze and kill him for my sport—
Th' industrious maid, with eager eye,
Should she my cob-web but espy,
With direful broom destroys it quite,
Nor gives me chance to live till night;
My fine spun web no mercy sees,
Away 'tis swept with careless ease:
Just so with man, for even he
From dire misfortune's seldom free;
For when with pains and anxious care
His house is rais'd, his prospect fair,
His hope, by Death's all-powerful sway,
Is like a cob-web swept away.—
In HOGARTH, you will ever find
The Moralist and Painter join'd;
And none could genius stretch forth wider—
He gave instruction from the Spider—
For me he has not left i'th' lurch;
Behold his print, where, in a church,
O'er poor's box, you'll a cob-web find;
Enough to tell the human mind,
That Charity is weak, no doubt,
When e'en a Cob-web keeps it out.
CORINNA, known in Drury-lane,
Like me, has many victims slain—
Her arts, the cob-web—fatal snare!
And giddy youth entangle there—
Be arts like her's by youth withstood,
Lest, spider-like, she seek e'en blood.—
With spirits low, my lady sick,
"Oh 'tis the death-watch; hear it tick"—
She listens—"nay, 'tis very clear—
"I'm certain now that death is near."—
The lady may dispel her fears,
'Tis not a death-watch which she hears;—
Then tell her (and be sure you chide her)
'Tis the Tarantula, or Spider.—
The Spider now has nearly done,
For, like her web, her theme is spun;—
Tho', lady-like, you'll not abide her,
Pray do not kill the little Spider.

DIV1.HEAD: On the French Expedition to BANTRY-BAY.
Animus est in Patinis.

LG.L: OH! cruel winds to waft away
The famish'd French from Bantry,
The sound misled them to the Bay,
They thought it meant DE PANTRY:
And still more pleas'd, when come so near,
It made them almost frisky,
For they had hop'd the Isle of Beer
Would prove an Isle of WHISKY:
While yet the howling winds resist,
They craving seek the Shannon,
And there, more ready for a twist,
We'll feed them from our cannon:
Thus, toss'd about, they try each Bay,
But, loyal, we disdain 'em;
For Irish souls know no dismay,
And wish to entertain 'em.
AS Cupid was a ready Boy
I taught him soon to read and write;
The Urchin, to my greatest joy,
Has form'd six letters with delight:
The Trident E came first to view,
The doughdy D then instant grew,
And, close, the united W:
The stradling A, by all that's good,
The first of letters, nobly stood;
Reluctant wrote, the little god,
The R, initial of the rod;
Again he drew the swelling D,
And, laughing, ask'd one word from me:
With EDWARD thus before my eyes
What could my anxious heart suffice?
So, calling on the Powers above,
Trembling I wrote, oh Edward, "LOVE!"
YOU say, my dear Sally, I cannot tell why,
A stanza or two I could write, if I try,
Let the subject you give me be just what it may;
And that e'en on a Pudding I've something to say.—
A Pudding, sweet Sall, I can shew in a trice.
Is a subject, of which I wou'd fain have a slice.—
The World is a Pudding of ev'ry ingredient,
Where each his own palate may suit as expedient;
Some folks have indeed (for it must be confess'd)
A slice of the Pudding too hard to digest;
While others expert, or more cunning or quick,
Contrive all the Plums and the Sweetmeats to pick:
Where I but to help them, and give each his share,
Good things they should have—but they all shou'd cut fair.—
Hasty Pudding and Custard our Childhood befriend:
Yorkshire Pudding and Dumpling in Youth we commend:
The Sportsman, whose shouts make the vallies to ring,
Will cry, at noon day, "Hunting Pudding's the thing."
Old Age best enjoys after Custard its nap;
And life still is cherish'd with infantine pap.
Thus the praises of Pudding we own in each stage,
At School and at College, in youth and in age.—
Each Sunday, I hope, will our Clergy afford
Roast Beef and Plum Pudding to smoke on the board;
Good Living, they tell us, the Puritan shocks;
With us, the Plum Pudding is quite orthodox—
At Oxford, unless with much learning you fast,
The New College Pudding will crown the repast.—
The Citizen owns, or must know at the least,
That Puddings of all sorts are found at his feast;
There's Custard, and Marrow, and Plum, and there's Tanzy,
Of all which he eats full as long as he can see.—
Yet a little slice more this one truth to unfold,
Tho' I fear that my Pudding by this time is cold,
That you with dear Paul are as fond as the dove,
And want no cold Pudding to settle your Love.
'TWAS BERNARD'S wish, when almost forty,
To take unto himself a wise;
He judg'd nice NEL had ne'er been naughty,
And ask'd her to be his for life.
But, strangely led by vicious passion,
Fair Helen to seduce, he try'd;
(Such things we hope are not the fashion)
Yet she his arts and wiles defy'd.
"My love, say'd he, the day is fix'd,
"Then let us now suppose we're married,
"For having vow'd, joy's lost betwixt
"The happy day, if thus we tarried.
When Nelly would not grant his suit,
Nor yield, altho' most warmly sought,
He strove, by force, to press her to't,
She still resisted—nay she fought.
Well—thus denied, they married soon,
And Bernard was a happy man,
But, e'er they'd pass'd the honey-moon,
He own'd he'd had a secret plan.—
He say'd "You must remember, Nelly,
"How much I press'd, tho' you denied,
"My ardent passion—Now, I'll tell you—
"No MARRIAGE, had you then complied".
To hear his baseness, she was vex'd;
"And were your vows all false and vain!
"Let not your mind then be distress'd,
"If you, from me, a secret gain".
"We women may, (when rightly taught)
"If once deceiv'd, become more quick;
"I then had my experience bought—
"From the young Squire I learnt the trick".

DIV1.HEAD: SYMPTOMS OF OBSTINACY. DEDICATED, BY PERMISSION, TO A FRIEND'S WIFE.

LG.L: BOB had a wife, but so perverse,
He almost wish'd her in her hearse:
To mend her temper was in vain;
Her spirit work'd against the grain.—
A fishing once she went in dudgeon,
And try'd the river for a gudgeon;
When reaching far to hook a bite,
Plump in she fell, went down outright,
Which Robin saw, but, in his fright,
Could scarcely hobble to the river,
His Kate from drowning to deliver;
Yet call'd aloud for some assistance,
When Will and Tom, from no small distance,
Flew to the bank, and found their Master
Quite frantic at the sad disaster—
The current was in rapid force,
And with it all things went of course;
They, therefore, put their boat-hooks down,
As the stream ran, to hitch her gown;
But lower they began their search,
Than where she'd fallen off the Perch.
"What fools you are," exclaim'd Old Robin,
"Thus with the tide your hooks to bob in;
"Go higher up," said patient Bob,
"The other were a fruitless job;
"Try, try, ABOVE the place, where Fate
"Thus robb'd me of my dearest Kate;
"Some chance there is in such a scheme,
"She ever went AGAINST the stream."—
The servants follow'd in a trice
Their Master's orders and advice,
And sound he was a knowing guide—
They hook'd her buffeting the tide.
WHILE Wits and Wags still have their jokes,
Or some pert Bard the Muse invokes,
To place good Wives of ev'ry station
Below the Lords of the Creation,
Allow a Friend to patient merit,
To Wives of kindness, not of spirit,
To trespass shortly on your time,
A homely tale to tell in rhyme.—
MARTHA was all a man could wish—
Her husband, JOHN, a strange odd fish,
Knew not the value of his wife,
But led her a most irksome life;
Thinking it was a husband's right
To contradict from morn to night;
And, as she patiently would sit
To hear him scold, or try at wit,
She hop'd, but all her hopes were vain
Some gentler treatment to obtain—
She soon discover'd that her Deary
Was after dinner much more cheery;
And, if his palate she could hit,
He sometimes lost the growling fit;
But these events were very rare;
Pat could not always, to a hair,
Set a nice dinner on the table,
Hot, smoking hot, nor yet was able
The time to keep, when, with the clock,
Bang at the door she heard his knock:
And now, to make the case quite clear,
A little anecdote you'll hear,
Proving good Martha's care at least,
To please her lawful-growling beast.—
John lov'd a pudding, or a tart,
But a BAK'D pudding won his heart;
One day this dainty crown'd the treat,
When Surly John refus'd to eat:
"You are not ill, sweet Love?" cry'd Pat,
Hoping to get him into chat;
"Always BAK'D pudding, never boil'd,
"Enough to drive a husband wild;
"'Twas bak'd on Saturday and Sunday;
"I swear I'll have it boil'd for one day."
The next day it was boil'd so nice,
She thought he'd eat it in a trice;
But she mistook her gentle Swain,
And could, nor thanks, nor smiles, obtain;
Snarling, he said, 'twas downright pap,
Which for the child she meant, mayhap—
Her little heart was full of trouble,
She boil'd one firmer, to a bubble;
And, lest in this she should mistake,
One to the Oven sent, to bake;
And, with the boil'd and bak'd together,
Her heart grew lighter than a feather,
Thinking, if one was wrong, the other
Would please, at least prevent all pother.—
Just then the hungry husband enter'd,
And, on the beef before he ventur'd,
Spies the two puddings on the board,
"Can I eat both?" exclaim'd her Lord;
She told him, (and the truth confess'd,)
She meant it only for the best—
"You surely have not common sense;
"Besides, you never mind expence,"—
Then with a sneer—"In future, pray,
"Do let three puddings dance the Hay."
The patient wife, so roughly treated,
And all her kind attempts defeated,
Now, with becoming spirit, rose,
And dar'd him thus again oppose
His cruel temper to her kindness,
For her submission had been blindness,
Bearing so long his savage force;—
But now she'd change her wonted course,
And let him learn that "Husbands owe
"That kindness which their Wives bestow—"
There needs no wisdom to discern,
A worm, when trod upon, will turn—
Tyrants, oppos'd, will soon give way:
John not a single word could say;
He seem'd to feel his own disgrace,
And hardly look'd in Martha's face—
Yet tried to turn it off in laughter,
But seldom growl'd from that day after.
HOW great was the Merit! What praise still is due
To the Man who invented a Carriage so clever!
A Carriage Amphibious he then had in view,
Which Neptune and Phaeton wish not to sever.
I'll just give its Model—A small Canvas House,
By a little Horse drawn, who'll not flounder nor splash,
And, supported by four Wheels, from whence you may souse,
Letting down, in due time, a huge Canvas Calash.
If much might be said on this famous Machine,
Tho' out of my depth very soon as a Poet,
As a mere Modest Smile is then all that I mean,
Were a hole in the Canvas, from me none should know it.
To prove well its Use, both for pleasure and health,
To RAMSGATE repair, and, betimes in the Morning,
Fresh vigour you'll gain, which surpasses all wealth,
When you take this Machine, and are under its Awning.
But let me describe, if I can in a Song,
The good kind of People, who crave its Assistance:
The Beaux and the Belles, who come tripping along,
And the Aged and Lame leave behind at a distance.
Here the smart looking Chambermaid carries the Dress
Of her Lady, for whom the Waves sigh as they heave,
Yet, perhaps you will say, were they bound to confess,
They the Abigall Wag-Tail had rather receive.
But the silver-foot Goddess appears now to tremble,
As her robe she unloosens, the waves all in motion,
Yet she quickly immerges, her fear to dissemble,
And rises, like Venus, again, from the Ocean.
The Pantaloon'd Dasher, and Great-coated Trimmer
Are as long in undressing as going to bed;
And each, afterwards, talks like an excellent swimmer,
Tho' he only crept in, and once popp'd down his head.
Then the sweet little Children (whom Betty attends,
But whose coaxing and kissing to bathe are rejected,
When she finds it in vain to persuade her young friends)
Are undressed, and the Guide gives a Souse unexpected.
Having now had MY Dip and been ready to founder,
(For without any Corks can I venture to swim?)
Of my Fancy, so poor, and my Judgment, not sounder,
YOUR PRAISE is a LIFE BOAT preserving the Whim.—
THIS is a Rose without a Thorn,
If to good Fortune you are born;
But, should you pennyless appear,
Think you to find sweet Comfort here?
No—you may shiver in the Street;
No bed of Roses will you meet;
Tho' hanging full-blown at the door,
It sheds no fragrance to the Poor—
Doth not the Sign the truth disclose?
Look up—It is The GOLDEN ROSE.—

DIV1.HEAD: On LOVE.

LG.L: OF all the Passions of the Human Mind
Affording Joys resembling Bliss above,
The genuine Passion, tho' to few confin'd,
Is that so justly call'd All-powerful Love.
As Health the seeble Body soon restores,
As the bright Eye is Magic to the Face,
So Love inflames the Soul, so Love adores,
And in its Object every Charm can trace.
Thrice happy Pair! by Nature's self design'd,
Blessing and bless'd, to prove such Joys are given,
(Uniting Virtues which exalt the Mind)
As make this Earth, with mutual Love, a HEAVEN.

DIV1.P: proposa en Mariage au Duc de RICHELIEU, qui aroit quatre vingts ans, une jeune Demoi∣lle qui n'en avoit que dix huit. Il la réfusa en lui fesant la chanson suivante.

DIV1.HEAD: AIR DE CE REFUS.

LG.L: DE ce refus, vous pénétrez la cause—
ous étes jeune, et j'ai quatre vingts ans:
ar un baiser, je fanerois la rose;
Et ce seroit un outrage au printems.
Pour un baiser ne croyez pas, bergère,
Que l'age rende un coeur indifférent;
Mais un baiser pourroit-il satisfaire,
Ke rendant pas le plaisir que l'on sent?
Il m'en souvient, j'avois une Maîtresse,
Fraiche, décente, aimable comme vous;
Elle eut votre air, j'avois votre jeunesse:
Et c'est alors que les Baisers sont doux.
Je dois à l'aimable jeunesse
Des biens si doux; elle a droit d'en jouir;
De mes beaux Jours il reste à ma vieillesse
Moins un regret qu'un heureux souvenir.

DIV1.P: When the Duke de RICHILIEU was 80 years old, a young Lady, only 18, was proposed to him in Marriage. He refused her in the following Sonnet.

LG.L: THE cause you at once can disclose—
You are young, and I eighty years bring:
By a kiss I should wither the rose;
It would quite be an outrage to spring.
Yet think not, fair Maiden, a kiss
No joy to old age still reveals;
But can it impart the true bliss,
Not giving the pleasure it feels?
I once had a Mistress, so fair,
Like yourself in perfection compleat;
And I had your youth, she your air:
It is then that the kisses are sweet.
The soft transports, to youth which I owe,
Lovely youth has a right to enjoy;
And, if less of regret I now show,
I a happy remembrance employ.

LG.HEAD: LES QUATRE SAISONS. A LAURE.
LG.L: QUAND je vois vos Attraits, c'est pour moi Le Printemps:
Quand je cueille un Baiser, c'est L'Eté; je moissonne:
Quand vous me prodiguez, dans vos Discours charmans,
Les Fruits de votre Esprit, j'amasse; c'est L'Automne:
Mais si, dans vos beaux Yeux ou dans votre Air,
Je vois de la Froideur, je tremble, c'est L'Hyver.

LG.HEAD: THE FOUR SEASONS. To LAURA.
LG.L: WHEN your Charms I behold, 'tis sweet Spring that I see;
When a Kiss I may take, a fine Summer to me;
When the Fruits of your Genius you lavishly pour,
My Autumn how rich! how abundant the Store!
But if, in your Air or your Eyes, there appear
The least Coolness to me, it is Winter severe.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: SI, pour embellir le monde,
Jupiter m'eût consulté,
Dans les lieux où coule l'Onde;
Le Vin seul eût existé:
La terre eût servi de Treille
Et la mèr de Réservoir;
Dont pour le mettre en bouteille
Il m'eut fait son Entonnoir.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: De tous les dieux que la fable
A mis dans son pantheon,
Il n'en est qu'un véritable,
Qui soit digne de ce nom:
C'est Bacchus que je veux dire;
Pour les autres immortels,
Je crois qu'un buveur peut rire
Jusqu'au pied de leurs autels.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Aussitôt que la lumière
A redorê nos côteaux,
Je commence ma carrière
Par visiter mes tonneaux;
Ravi de revoir l'Aurore
Le verre en main, je lui dis:
Vois tu sur la rive More,
Plus qu'en mon Nez de Rubis?

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: Le plus grand roi de la terre,
Quand je suis dans un repas,
S'il me déclaroit la guerre,
Ne m'épouvanteroit pas.
A table rien ne m'etonne;
Et je pense, quand je bois,
Si le grand Jupiter tonne,
Que c'est qu'il a peur de moi.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Si quelque jour étant ivre
La mort arrêtoit mes pas,
Je ne voudrois point revivre
Pour changer ce doux trépas.
Je m'en irois dans l'averne
Faire enivrer Alecton,
Et bâtir une taverne
Dans le manoir de Pluton.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: Par ce nectar délectable
Les démons étant vaincus,
Je ferois chanter an diable
Les louanges de Bacchus,
J'appaiserois de Tantale
La vive altération;
Et passaut l'onde infernale,
Je ferois boire Ixion.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: bout de ma quarantaine
nt Ivrognes m'ont promis,
venir, la tasse pleine,
gite où l'on m'aura mis;
ur me faire une Hécatombe,
i signale mon destin,
arroseront ma tombe
e plus de cent broes de vin.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: e marbre ni de porphyre
u'on ne fasse mon tombeau;
e ne veux pour tout élire
ue le contour d'un Tonneau:
t veux qu'on peigne ma trogne
vec ces vers alentour:
Ci-git le plus grand Ivrogne,
Qui jamais ait vu le jour."

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: HAD Jupiter wish'd to embellish
The world, and consulted with me,
He'd have fill'd, (oh the thought how I relish!)
With Wine, not with water the sea:
In my scheme, there cou'd nothing be plainer,
Where waters flow'd, wine was my notion;
The earth shou'd have serv'd as a Strainer;
And the great Reservoir been the ocean:
To bottle it off, it cou'd never have run-ill,
Had Jupiter pleas'd to have made me his Funnel.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Of the gods, whom the old fable places
To fill the pantheon, so fam'd,
There is but one deity graces
The temple, or fit to be nam'd;
It is Bacchus, whose praises I quaff;
I leave all the others alone,
For I think that a toper wou'd laugh
Where he plac'd at the foot of their throne.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: As soon as the sun does adorn
Our hills, I begin my career,
And fail not to visit, each morn,
My casks, where my spirits I cheer;
When charm'd with Aurora I've been,
I say, as my glass I disclose,
"On the African banks hast thou seen
"A ruby surpassing my nose?"

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: The greatest of kings in the world,
When I'm taking, like Bacchus, my feast,
(Shou'd, against me, wars vengeance be hurl'd,)
Wou'd not frighten nor vex me the least;
I am never alarm'd, as I dine,
If great Jupiter's thunder I hear,
For I think, as I'm quaffing my wine,
That of me, it but shows his vast fear.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Shou'd one day, when drunk, as I range,
Fate seize me, through envy malign,
I wou'd not revive if to change,
A death that's so happy in wine;
At once to Avernus I'd go,
Make Alecto quite drunk; and I'd build,
On Pluto's own manor below,
A tavern with wine nobly fill'd.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: O'ercome, by such Nectar delightful,
Those regions wou'd joyously ring;
And the daemons, discordant and frightful,
The praises of Bacchus shou'd sing;
The unassuag'd thirst I'd appease
Of Tantalus passing the Styx,
That lake so infernal, to please
Old Ixion, with liquor, I'd six.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: At the end, then, of my quarantine,
A hundred choice drunkards averr'd,
That they each, with a goblet of wine,
Wou'd come, where their patron's interr'd;
And to make for me that Hecatomb,
Which so signal a fate had provok'd,
They'd a hundred full hogsheads consume,
In bathing the tomb, till it soak'd.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: Neither marble nor porph'ry I ask
For my vault—they may do as they please;
Only make the circumf'rence a Cask,
And I shall rest fully at ease;
I wish that, my picture to draw,
This distich, around, might appear,
"Of all who the light ever saw,
"The greatest of drunkards lies here."
WHAT emblom, symbol, metaphor or trope
Can best describe the bounding ANTELOPE?
Not the swift Deer, that is in forests seen,
But the brave CALVERT'S Antelope marine,
Which o'er the ocean bounds, and scuds away,
Rides through the gale, nor needs the friendly bay;
She, who the praise of all may fairly boast,
When with her friends she glides along the coast;
Friends most select, whose joy no sorrows check,
Whose festive mirth re-echoes from her deck;
Where true good humour constantly prevails,
And love and friendship fill the swelling sails;
Where no excesses will that joy o'erwhelm,
Which pleasure gives, while prudence takes the helm:
To let our sancy, then, have greater scope,
Joy is the emblem, Friendship is the trope
Of the brave CALVERT'S bounding ANTELOPE.
WHEN republican FRANCE would all monarchs dethrone,
A bold little CORSICAN soon cur'd the evil,
The empire he seized, and, thus, made it his own;
And Citizen Frenchman he sent to the Devil.
HIS Princes arose, and Electors were Kings,
And HOLLAND, heel-upwards, he now takes in tow;
If cowardly rascals submit to such things,
This world will become then a mere puppet show.
Oh abject BATAVIA! who shook off the yoke,
With courage, undaunted, of old haughty SPAIN;
Will you ask for the shackles, and not strike a stroke,
The shackles of FRANCE too, and six them again!—
AS JACK was reeling to and fro,
With Quid well tuck'd within his cheek,
A pleasant friend, who fain would know
The utmost joy the tar could seek,
Told him, THREE WISHES he might make,
Which he would grant, by magic art;
Besides the Girl he'd like to take
To captivate his generous heart.—
JACK.—
"First, all the RUM that's in the world—
"And all the BACKEY, for my next"—
Then puzzling, as his stick he twirl'd,
Jack, for a third wish, seem'd perplex'd:—
"What", says his friend, "is now to come?
"Nay, wish once more," "Well, then, MORE RUM".
BY old Rochester's Clock (and it was not yet dark)
'Twas a quarter past six, ere I saw Madam Clark—
Much she curtsey'd and drew herself up at the Door,
And thought you were coming i'th' old coach and four
With Children and Servants at least half a score—
"Mrs. Townley is well? and the dear little creatures?
"So lovely a Groupe! with such sweet pretty features!
"How many, pray Sir, is it now that you boast?
"Is it five, six, or seven, perhaps, at the most?"
While thus full of the Praises of all the sweet Boys,
She was presently stopp'd by a clattering and noise
Of Horses and Servants, with two or three Chaises;
The bar-bell she rings, and her shrill voice she raises;
'Twas "Ostler" and "Chambermaid" echo throughout,
And the Waiters are scampering and flying about;
While Jem with his Hamlet trots up to the Stable
And provides for himself then as well as he's able.
But, my dear pretty Mary, methinks you will say,
"I wish my good Man, in a regular way,
"Would but tell me, in verse, all the Scenes of the Day."
To please then my Love, though she laughs at my verse,
I will grant her request—and 'tis thus I rehearse—
My Horse, my good Hamlet! "scarce ever caught tripping,
"Who goes without Spur, and who never wants whipping,"
To the old City brought me—which I, in a banter,
For shortness in verse, and on Horseback, call Canter—
It had not sruck ten when I reach'd the Red Lion—
Within the three Hours! need I faster to hie on?—
Having fed my good Beast, tho' I just saw him dress'd,
I thought it but right I should give him some rest,
While I scrap'd well my face, and fresh powder'd my hair,
Since to see a new Client I strait must repair;
You know whom I mean, Mr. Cumming th' Attorney,
Whom I promis'd to call on i'th' course of my Journey;
Much he press'd me to dinner, and good Mrs. Cumming
Would fain give me Wine, or some Water, with Rum in;
But so fix'd was my Plan before night to see Rochester,
I refus'd all their Liquors, nay even their Dorchester;
Having weigh'd well the Case, and the Papers and Pleas,
And enlarg'd on the merits—and hinted at Fees,
I then took my leave; and, in going along,
I just paid a visit to old Mrs. Tong,
By whose clack call her Tongue—and you'll not name her wrong.
Tho' my stay there was short, too much time had I spent,
And to one Mr. —'s Mansion I went;
Yet so great was my haste, he'd not press me to stay—
But hop'd the next time—to be out of the way.—
I went to the Church, to inspect the good Pew;
I must call it good, from the Place—and the Stew
Which my Client is in—who must have her own will,
And keep the Possession—as Grist to the Mill;
When her Case is but doubtful she's sure she is right,
And to hear all her reasons, would keep me all night—
I wish'd her success, since her Cause is but Justice,
But as to the Law sure too strong now her trust is.
As I look'd at my Watch, when my visits were done,
How great my Surprize, when I found it was one—
Have I spent the whole morning, within this old City?
'Tis a great deal to lose, and I'm sure 'tis a Pity,
As the days are much shorten'd, and draw in apace,
Besides I hate riding, as if for a race—
I return'd to the Inn, and I thought I could eat,
In a twinkling, a morsel of any cold meat—
My Landlady shew'd me boil'd beef and cold ham,
But I spied in the larder some nice ribs of lamb—
Bring 'em out—"Would you choose, Sir, to have a potatoe"?
Oh bravo! I'll eat it—'twill make me no later—
The stage was a long one—I'd breakfasted soon,
And had had a good ride, and 'twas now afternoon—
So I trust you'll agree with your Jemmy and say,
Take a snap while you can—it's the very best way—
But first I should tell you, I happen'd to meet
A very old friend, as he pass'd in the street;
It was one you may know, not a female or hoyden;
But my friend Mr. Fuller, of Updown—and Croydon;
He kindly stay'd with me, and saw me devour
My cold ribs of lamb, i'th' fourth part of an hour—
We parted—I paid, and I mounted my Hamlet
And away from old Canter—to Sittingbourne amble it—
I reach'd Mrs. Fordred's, the farthest Red Lion,
Before five o'Clock—not so slow to cry, fye on—
I stay'd forty minutes, in sipping my tea,
Saw Hamlet well dress'd—and then gave him his Fee—
Refresh'd, I remounted, and reach'd the King's Head,
The time most exactly already you've read.—
The Day was delightful, sweet, pleasant and airy;
Not a Cloud to be seen, but on parting with Mary:
'Tis a little past ten, and I've eat some veal cutlet,
But you know that at night I don't wish much to guttle it,—
I will now go to bed, having scribbled, you see,
What perhaps may amuse you, as coming from me.
With Love to good Uncle, Aunt, Babies and Bess;
Whom I cannot love more, and I should not love less,
I remain, my dear Mary, (my Faults then forgive)
Your affectionate Husband, as long as I live.

DIV1.HEAD: TO MY MARY ON HER BIRTH-DAY, 24th Dec. 1788.

LG.L: DOTH then my dearest Love complain
That I invoke the Muse
To sing the Worth of Nymph or Swain
And Praise to Her refuse?
The merest trifle to confer,
Which Friendship may impart,
Can it produce a Sigh in Her
Possessing full my Heart?
Were I to sing her Worth and Praise
On such a Day as This,
And fain would I in grateful Lays
Describe my long-known Bliss.
Each friendly Muse I should entreat
To grant poetic Fire,
While fill'd with Joy, in Notes most sweet,
Apollo sweeps the Lyre.—
But humbler Strains, thus bless'd with Truth,
Content a Husband's Mind,
Who knew her Worth in early Youth,
Her Heart to Love inclin'd:
When fifteen fleeting Years have pass'd
And goodness never ceas'd,
Each Year more fleeting than the last
Because his Bliss encreas'd:
When Genius mark'd her for his own,
In various Gifts express'd,
And highest Merit can be shewn
While MOTHER stands confess'd,
While further Charms she may display,
Sense, Fortitude, and Worth,
My Babes and I will bless the Day
That gave such Virtues Birth.
TWO little Striplings send their Love,
Their Duty, they should say;
'Tis both, they send, like Hand and Glove,
And thus most humbly pray—
To-morrow, as Old Records tell,
To Love and Hymen true,
A Pair, with whom sweet Peace shall dwell,
Will hail the Day with you.
Tho' sixteen Years are gone and fled,
And chequer'd Scenes have past,
Yet still, by Truth and Virtue led,
May Heaven's Protection last!
Permit us then to join the Pair,
Our Absence were neglect;
And, while such Happiness we share,
We'll bless the Cause, and you th' Effect.

DIV1.HEAD: To Captain and Mrs. NEVILLE, WITH A GOOSE.

LG.L: TOO soon for St. Michael, accept from my Store,
And I hope it will prove to your Goût,
A tender young Goose, who will waddle no more,
Nor e'er cackle at me, or at you:
While certain, at once, your own Palates to hit,
Sage and Onion you need not to waste,
Well season'd with Friendship, good Humour and Wit,
You will serve it up quite to your Taste.
WHILE Cramer's Notes delight th' attentive Ear,
And Neville's Verse such friendly Truths impart,
Those Sounds melodious shall my Spirits chear,
Those flowing Numbers shall improve my heart.
"But quit, thou cry'st, the Feast and Midnight Song,
"Hygeia calls thee to substantial Joys;
"Obey the Goddess, leave the busy Throng,
"And, come, enjoy her with thy Girls and Boys."
I'll seek the Hill, where Health with Nature reigns,
Where Love and Innocence together meet,
Where worldly Care no longer drags his Chains,
And Friendship makes the happy Hours compleat:
There will I view those Scenes, thy Lines bestow,
The Mountain's Brow, sweet Vale and sportive Field,
Whose Beauties, charming, like thy Colors glow,
Which only can to Nature's Pencil yield.—
THE Report of the Bishop of Chichester's Death is untrue—
—The Rowing Match was accordingly deferred.
The Party at Brighton is in fact Comus's Court—
—No finer Pickles to be had.
To be disposed of, an old-established Business—
—The last Dividend will be on the 1st of April.
Old Parr died at the Age of 152—
—The Court of Chancery having just determined the Suit.
To be Sold by Private Contract—
—Whereupon he was declared duly elected.
Accounts from Jersey advise—
—And they were all sent to the House of Correction.

DIV1.HEAD: Mrs. TOWNLEY's ADDRESS TO THE RAMSGATE VOLUNTEERS On her presenting to them their COLOURS.
DIV1.P: THE VOLUNTEERS of RAMSGATE have long, and deservedly, possessed the Reputation due to Military Excellence, Good Conduct, Spirit and Loyalty.
I shall ever esteem it a most distinguished Honour, that I am permitted to dedicate, to the Use of the Corps, these COLOURS, on which the Labours of my Pencil have been em∣ployed.

Slight as such Offerings may be, either from their own Merits, or from any that belong to the Person who presents them, they are, at least, sincere Proofs of that Respect and Attachment to You, which I share in common with the In∣habitants of this Place and Neighbourhood.

Please to confer upon me the Honour of accepting them on this Occasion; and I only express the universal Opinion, when I say that in your Possesion, and under your Auspices, they will, on all Occasions, be employed for Purposes con∣nected with the general Defence of our Country; and with the Prosperity of RAMSGATE in particular.

LG.L: DEAR Mary, since, from early Days,
Thy Virtues claim'd the warmest praise
To real merit due;
Let us enrich this happy day,
And bring at once, in simple lay,
Sweet scenes to our review.
When, from parental Whitton's shade,
I led my not unwilling maid
To Twickenham's ancient tower,
A Brother, 'twas a Brother's part,
In wedlock join'd each hand and heart;
All hail'd the happy hour.
Here let me drop the pious tear
For those we ever shall revere,
While Parents claim our love;
Whose aged heads have bent to time,
Whose virtues taught them best to climb
And seek true bliss above.
As years ran on (and swift they flew)
Sweet lovely bantlings round us grew,
And sought thy tender care;
They sought not, for, like Parent Earth,
Thou gav'st them, from the very birth,
Thy nature's amplest share.
I cannot stop—for oh the Joy!
To see the Insant Girl and Boy
Cling to thy loving arms;
To mark thy Skill and constant Thought,
A Mother's Heart by Wisdom taught,
All adding to thy Charms.
If, in my Praise, thou'lt deign a Word,
While I, in thine, would fain be heard,
Revealing thus my Store,
Thou'lt say, "'twas then my James, so true,
"Cheerful his Labours would pursue,
"While tugging at the Oar."
And further still my Mary's heart
New scenes of kindness did impart
To cheer th' afflicted Lot;
For, to a Brother's wish inclin'd,
She shew'd a tender Sister's mind,
And made one happy Cot.
Blest Highgate then be ever dear!
While gently falls the swelling tear
Of warmest Love and Joy;
Our Trio, like their honour'd Sire,
For bliss receiv'd did bliss inspire,
And thus their hours employ.
But now what pleasure fills the mind,
When bounteous Heaven to us so kind,
Each grateful bosom cheers;
When Ramsgate is our Highgate still,
When Love like ours shall never chill,
But be increas'd with years.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE Right Hon. Sir WILLIAM SCOTT, MAJOR COMMANDANT OF THE ASSOCIATED CORPS OF CIVILIANS. 1799.
PRO ARIS ET FOCIS.

LG.L: A NATION, great in COMMERCE, ARTS, and ARMS,
Hears with Disdain the Insolence of Foes;
Firm in herself, she fears not War's Alarms,
Nor seeks unwisely, all its direful Woes.
But when new Doctrines have Mankind misled,
When peaceful States in Anarchy are hurl'd,
When powerful Nations bend their mighty Head,
Then ENGLAND RISES AND PROTECTS THE WORLD.
Then shall her FLEETS such glorious Victories gain,
While dire Disgrace the Foe infernal guides,
That Arabs shout, astonish'd, and the Main
Heaves its proud Bosom, where a NELSON rides.
And still, by Wisdom led, RELIGION'S Dome
On its firm Basis will unshaken stand,
While CORPS of LOYALTY protect at Home
The Blessings which curich this happy Land.
But one PECULIAR CORPS demands the Song—
Vers'd in the LAW OF NATIONS, well they know
The Rights inherent that to all belong,
When all OBEY the Law from which they slow.
ASSOCIATES CIVIL! Eloquent and sage,
Who plead for Justice, and for Virtue sight;
Or Law declare, from Learning's ancient Page,
And soften Rigour when maintaining Right.
While YOUNGER SONS of this distinguish'd Band,
In Vigour strong, with martial Genius soar,
Eager to take the honourable Stand
Of active Soldiers in the CIVIL CORPS.

DIV1.HEAD: RULES, To be observed at LITTLE SHERWOOD BALL, Prescribed, without Ceremony, by the Master of the Ceremonies, and extracted from the celebrated Work of FIGURINI.
DIV1.P: 1. WHEN the Company is assembled, the Fans of the several Ladies are to be collected by the Master of the Ceremonies, and by him presented to the Gentlemen; and on each Gentleman's receiving a Fan, he shall accept it in the most respectful man∣ner, pointing the tip of it towards his Heart, and then, graceful∣ly returning it to the fair Owner, he shall dance with her two Dances.
2. No Lady is to disown her Fan.

3. If any Gentlemen from hurry of Spirits, Excess of Politeness, being left-handed, or otherwise aukward, should break, or in the least injure a Fan, he is the next Morning early to send the Lady a new one, and, by way of excuse, a Copy of Verses, every word being properly spelt. Copies of them afterwards, given to the Master of the Ceremonies, will be thankfully received, to form a choice Collection for future Assemblies here.

4. As it is well known that much beauty and Sweetness of Man∣ners will grace the Assembly, every Gentlemen will doubtless observe the greatest Respect and Decorum on the Occasion, and
will not give rise to any Challenge, Quarrel or Misunderstand∣ing, so that no Gentleman need be provided with more than his usual two Cases of Pistols.

5. Should there unexpectedly be a Duel, and the Gentleman who was not in the least the Aggressor, unfortunately fall, he shall be buried with the Honors of Love, the Ladies attending in white Crape Veils.

6. Any Lady fainting, or appearing to faint, or saying she is sure she shall faint soon, the Master of the Ceremonies is to be called, but the Bell is not to be pulled down with ringing hastily for Assistance. Every Smelling Bottle may however be immediately offered, and sprinkling of Lavender Water, &c. freely allowed.

7. There will be a smart Supper provided, and the Ladies and Gentlemen will sit in Pairs; but if, through Necessity, they should sit pretty close, and a Gentleman through Politeness, should be very assiduous, in helping a Lady to the Wing of a Chicken, or a Merry Thought, and the Lady receive it with very peculiar Sweetness, the Gentleman is not to be certain the Lady is in Love with him; nor is the Lady to expect a Letter from him the next Morning declaring his tender Passion.
8. Bon Mots, Sallies of Wit, agreeable Fancies, and Quaint Con∣ceits, will be well received. No doubt the Gentlemens' Repar∣tees will be correct and decorous.

9. It is recommended that no Lady, after her return Home, keep her Female Friend up above one Hour, in describing the smart Things said to her; or her Ideas of any particular Gentleman's particular Attention, &c. but she may resume the Subject the very next Morning at eleven.

10. This being the first, and a kind of Rehearsal of a Ball at Lit∣tle Sherwood, the Master of the Ceremonies hopes for the Indul∣gence of his Friends, as he does for the Pleasure of their Com∣pany again very soon, assuring them that whatever Praise is due, it belongs to the Lady of the Manor, Donna Isabella.

CLOSER.SIGNED: J. T. M. C. CUPID, Secretary.

DIV1.HEAD: The MASTER of the CEREMONIES CARD after the BALL.
DIV1.P: THE Master of the Ceremonies takes the earliest Op∣portunity of returning his courteous Thanks to the Ladies and Gen∣glemen who honored him with their Company last Night, and assures the Ladies that their elegant Appearance, attractive Beauty, charm∣ing Grace, and sweetness of Manners captivated him; and, in the gay and correct Deportment of the Gentlemen, he felt the highest Satisfaction.
Having a slight touch of the Gout he was prevented pursuing the Mazes of the Dance, or shewing a light fantastic Toe, as he could have wished.
It will be a great Pleasure to him to learn, by the Messenger, Cupid, that no Cold has dared to attack his Friends on their return Home.

DIV1.HEAD: On the DEATH of a CHILD.

LG.L: OH! though you nurs'd the tender Plant,
And gently fann'd it as you sigh'd,
Giving it all that Love could grant—
The sweetest Lilly droop'd and died.—
AS I find I grow old, though I'm still pretty hoddy,
No Time should be lost now, or lavish'd away;
For my Mind I'd improve, and e'en strengthen my Body—
"—'Tis too late, says a Whisper, too late in the Day"—
Then I'll yet pass the Minutes, I have to enjoy,
With the Friends whom I love, with my Children and Wife,
Do good where I can, for that never will cloy,
Shed the Rays of true Friendship, the Sunshine of Life—
May I thus, full of Gratitude, due to kind Heav'n,
For Blessings like these, having then run my Race,
(And hoping my Frailties may all be forgiven,)
Life calmly resign, that my Sons take my Place.
AT tranquil TOTHAM every Joy is found—
The happy Trio, innocently gay,
With grateful Hearts, good Cheer, and Judgment sound,
In Love and Friendship pass the peaceful Day.
The CONSTANT COUPLE share each others Joy;
Suppress the Griefs that fill the anxious Heart;
Alike the fleeting Hours of Love employ;
Each Care divide, each tender Wish impart.
While lov'd HONORIA, of a Temper sweet,
Of modest Mind, unconscious of her Worth,
Where Truth and Innocence each other greet,
Shall bless the Hour that gave such Virtues birth.
But jocund now the merry Bells proclaim
The VICAR'S natal Day, so justly dear;
The Village Swains re-echo quick his Name,
While their full Harvest-Song shall reach the Ear.
The Day we'll honour with the choicest Liquor;
We know his Merits, and are proud to own 'em—
Here's to the Health then of the worthy VICAR
Of TOTHAM MAGNA—in a MAGNUM BONUM!!!

DIV1.HEAD: On the BIRTH-DAY of my dear Sister Mrs. BROOKS.
JULY 9, 1802.

LG.L: TO hail the glad morn that gave birth to our Bess,
To shew the fond Love we so warmly possess,
My feeble attempts will defy;
But, oh! may kind Providence grant her his Grace,
While her Virtues we sing, and her Merit we trace,
Or paint the sweet Innocence seen in her Face,
And the Goodness that shines in her Eye.
Minor Poets, like me, may describe common Worth,
But none but the Muses would sing at her Birth,
Or half her kind Soul could impart;
'Tis they that would hail the dear Female, forsooth,
Her Diffidence, Modesty, Goodness, and Truth,
With the Conduct of Age, and the Spirit of Youth,
From her Eye that expresses her Heart.
"Then let us reward such a Damsel as this,
"And give her for Life a due portion of Bliss,"
Said Hymen, and rais'd his sweet Voice,
"I'll be bound, and for ever be judg'd by her Looks,
"She'll truly be bless'd while united to BROOKS!"
"You are right, and her Eye," said Apollo, "Odzooks!
"It will sparkle, whose Heart shall rejoice."
NOW let me Verse and Love entwine,
And Blessings waft to Caroline;
And let me thank her for her Letter,
Which, like herself, need not be better,
And let me wish, as well as she,
That, like a Bird, I were but free
To fly o'er Hills, and Ways tho' heavy,
Nor wait for Turnpike Roads, to levy
Those Kisses, which the Sweets combine
Of dear Mamma and Caroline.

DIV1.HEAD: ON THE MUCH LAMENTED DEATH OF MR. MAYHEW.

LG.L: WELL read in Physic's useful Art,
With Nature for his constant rule,
With Knowledge of the human Heart,
And Practice as the greatest School;
With Friendship, Modesty and Truth,
A Mind as cheerful as serene,
With Judgment from his early Youth,
And Prudence in the Golden Mean;—
When Liberality and Grace
The proffer'd Fee would oft' decline,
And, to relieve the poor Man's Case,
All Ease or Comfort would resign;
When such a GALEN we could bring,
Disease would fly our happy Shores;
But, while his Praises thus we sing,
RAMSGATE, alas! his Loss deplores.—

DIV1.HEAD: THE DEGREE OF A. B.
Taken by my Son CHARLES at Merton College, Oxford.

LG.L: A CLEVER, handsome, Oxford Spark,
Who Learning swallow'd, like a Shark,
Once stood for his Degree;
The Tutors found his Classic Store,
And would not put one Question more,
So bid him write A. B.
Then to his Dad he pens a Letter,
Not Alma Mater could write better,
To let old Square-toes see
How great his Title now at College,
How vast, of course, his depth of Knowledge,
For—dash—he signs A. B.
Old Hunks, who was not always right,
Thought that A. B. might mean A Bite,
Or Money was his End,
So call'd his Wife to shew her Learning,
She said A. B. from her discerning,
Arch Bishop did portend.
SINCE dear Honoria, in her Nuptial Hour,
Claims and inspires my warmest votive Lay,
While Love and Hymen jointly lend their power
To bless and celebrate this happy Day,
Long may her Virtues meet their due Reward!—
—Fair is the Prospect which the Bridegroom gives;
He, as the Faithful Shepherd, will regard
The gentle Lamb that in his Bosom lives.
NATURE, once wishing to combine
All Virtues in the choicest Mould,
Produc'd with Joy, sweet Caroline,
And Love the Graces did unfold.—
Then Sense and Judgment took their part,
And warm Affection fill'd her Soul,
And native Modesty her Heart,
While firm Religion crown'd the Whole.

DIV1.HEAD: On FIVE NEW APOTHECARIES settling at HIGHGATE, UPON MR. FORSTER's DEATH.

LG.L: TO Highgate when FIVE DOCTORS came,
Who all must physic, blister, bleed,
I own it shook my very Frame;
Their Case, or ours, is bad indeed.

DIV1.HEAD: LITTLE LUCY'S DREAM

HEAD.HI: At BOARDING SCHOOL, The Night before a Ball.

DIV1.P:
WELL—I dreamt the Day arrived,—or rather the Night—and that the School Room was lighted up for the Ball— all the young Ladies were in their best Bibs and Tuckers, as my Grand Papa calls it—the Teachers had French Hats—the two Half-Boarders had laid out all the little Money their Parents al∣lowed them, to set themselves off; and the Dancing Master ap∣peared in a new Pair of white Silk Stockings; while my stately Governess was so rich in her Dress, we were more frightened at her than ever—nay, the first day we came, and were shewn into the Parlour, (never yet seen in disorder) was nothing to her Ap∣pearance at this time—Parents themselves were now respectful to a degree—and some of the little Children look'd up at her only once—the Maids, who were nearly worn out with fatigue, from having spent the whole day in dressing the young Ladies, stood, if the door was opened, peeping over each others shoulders to have a view of the brilliant Ball Room, and of our grand Gover∣ness—and ugly old Joseph, the Footman, had blacked his shoes so highly on the occasion, we thought they were japanned, besides having out a Frill, for the first time.—The Parents, the rich ones, of some of us, were seated on the best forms, with a few young
Bridlers they brought with them—I pitied the poor Writing Master, who, tho' he had two Daughters and a Niece there, and had mended the Pens, ruled the Books and rapped the Knuckles of the whole School for more than twenty Years, was obliged to stand behind, near the Door, because his Gait was rather awk∣ward, and his worked-white Sattin Waistcoat was still fresh, tho' not in itself, yet in every body's recollection on such days.—

Well, now, what do you think?—at this moment, as I dreamt, HARLEQUIN jumped into the room, over the little Orchestra, twirled round three times, tripped up the Dancing Master, flou∣rished his wooden Spatter, smacked the Grand Piano, and, in an instant, the School Room was turned into a large PASTRY COOK'S SHOP,—when Harlequin, frisking round, presented to the young Ladies, Tartlets, Cheesecakes, and Jellies; to the Half Boarders and Teachers, Pusss and whipt Syllabubs; to the Dan∣eing Master a Trisle; to the Writing Master a stale Bun; and to my Governess a rich Twelfth Cake.
Seeing so many nice things, and hastily reaching out my hand I gave my Bed-fellow such a Shove as awoke her and my∣self too.

LG.L: DEAF as a Post was my dear Dad,
Bawl as you would, or rave like mad,
He knew not what you said;
The Case is alter'd quite compleat,
For now a Whisper in the Street,
Will wake him in his Bed.
What shall I do? I've learnt to sing,
To SQUALL, he says, is more the Thing;
And tells me, with a Smile,
A little Distance I should keep,
If I must Sing, when he's asleep;
"What Distance pray?"—"A Mile."
OH my poor Bird! my songster sweet farewell—
The flute melodious, or the clearest fife
Could not your strong and warbling note excel—
—You gain'd your liberty and lost your life.—
Oft' have I heard thee twitter to the dawn;
And oft' have seen thee spread each flutt'ring wing,
As if to greet me with the rosy morn,
Which, with thy song, would be perpetual Spring.
Ah, cruel fate! to snatch my Bird away,
My little warbler, whom we all admir'd;
Cheerful he liv'd; and, happy, clos'd his day,
For in my Mary's bosom he expir'd.

DIV1.HEAD: THE DUETT.
On Friend SAFFERY's Singing with my Niece KITTY, "Time has not thinn'd my flowing Hair.—"

LG.L: IF Time has thinn'd his flowing Hair,
And bent him with an envious spite,
He still can join the lovely fair,
Whose Accents sweet the Ear delight.
Let him enjoy the cheerful Day,
His Taste and Knowledge to impart,
Let her that Excellence display,
That Modesty which gains the Heart.

DIV1.HEAD:
The HAPPY PARTY at CHARLTON.
Mrs. Sprigg,
Mrs. Evans,
Mrs. Benfield,
Mrs. Lane,
Mrs. George Townley,
Rev. G. S. Townley.
29th MAY, 1805.

LG.L: WHEN the Sisters danc'd round the good Brother,
And gave to Affection a Boon,
The Love thus express'd for each other,
Shone forth like the Sun at high noon:
Then at Charlton's delightful retreat
In their Praises the Village had rung,
For there's surely when five Sister's meet,
Tho' ne'er Lackington, no Lack in Tongue.
Since their days then in Love they employ,
One wish let an Old Friend present,
"That the Sisterhood long may enjoy
"Firm Health, their good Name and Content."

DIV1.HEAD: PIPE PAPERS
To ELIZA, On her observing, in the last Letter from India,—"If my dear Father has not PIPE PAPERS enough, it is not my Fault."—

LG.L: WHEN thy fond Father takes his Pipe,
And, full of Fun, with Judgment ripe,
Wishing for thee to crown his Bliss,
To light it he will ne'er produce
Thy Letters, but with this Excuse,
"To fancy ev'ry Whiff a Kiss.

DIV1.HEAD: On my dear SISTER SCOTT'S VERSES UPON HER RECOVERY.

LG.L: FULL was her Heart, with Love her Bosom glow'd;
And her rich Fancy told, in Accents sweet,
The Joy that pious Gratitude bestow'd;
While Genius own'd the happy Lines complete.
"And can you ever be repaid"? she cry'd—
—Oh! let those Sufferings cease, her Patience bore;
Let Health and Cheerfulness again abide
Within her Mansion, and we ask no more.
Are not her Virtues, Talents, Wit and Sense,
Rewards sufficient for our friendly part?—
—While Heaven shall please such blessings to dispense,
With Joy will beat each warm and feeling Heart.

P.HI: The following are the Lines alluded to*.

DIV1.HEAD: ON MY RECOVERY. THE FOLLOWING LINES ARE ADDRESSED AND DEDICATED, WITH A HEART FULL OF GRATITUDE AND JOY, TO MY DEAR SISTERS.

LG.L: WHO nurs'd me nine long ling'ring years,
Thro' sickness, sorrow, pains, and fears,
And yet supprest their starting tears?
MY SISTERS,
Who comforted my troubled mind,
By looks, and words, so sweet and kind?
(Which some poor mortals never find)
MY SISTERS.
Who left their friends and parties gay,
To watch in silence, night and day,
By turns to sooth, to grieve, to pray?
MY SISTERS.
Who fed me on their bended knees,
And cramp'd their limbs to give me ease,
And try'd each little art to please?
MY SISTERS.
Who, without shoes, wou'd softly creep,
And gently stooping take a peep
To see if I had dropt asleep?
MY SISTERS.
Whose fond affection cheer'd my gloom,
Who trod on tip-toe in my room,
And stirr'd the fire with bits of broom?
MY SISTERS.
Whose cheerfulness could so beguile,
As caus'd the invalid to smile,
And bless you in her heart the while?
MY SISTERS.
Who gently smooth'd my pillow-case,
Wiping the tears from off my face,
And printing kisses in their place?
MY SISTERS.
Returning health, by your kind aid,
Glows through my frame, now firmer made,
But can you ever be repaid?
MY SISTERS.
Yet, while your tender love I prize,
Your virtues soar above the skies,
Where your reward most surely lies,
MY SISTERS.
MANY, oh many happy years!
To you, my Love, and all our Dears;
And may the merry months and weeks
Bring smiles and roses to your cheeks—
Then live and love and laugh so gaily,
Not once a month, or week, but daily,
That ev'ry year, that glides away,
Be but a longer happy day.

DIV1.HEAD: FAMILY PRESENTS. January 2, 1806.
DIV1.P: NOTWITHSTANDING the complaints you make of the plague and trouble which you have with your large family, owing to the want of that respect which our parents received from us, yet I think you would find some relief by purchasing, as it were, a readiness and civility in them, occasionally making your children presents of money or of different articles; to ex∣plain what I mean, I send you an account of what I recollect to have lately done for such purpose, and by way of inducing them to let the remainder of my life, spent in toil and anxiety to place them in the very comfortable situations in which they now are, pass away with some degree of satisfaction and repose.
I. To my eldest Son an increase of Salary, on his appearing sorry when I was extremely ill.

II. A shilling a-piece to each of the little children to induce them not to make so great a noise at that time—note—I found this had better been left alone, for they all laughed immoderately after it.—
III. To my second Son, thinking I might induce him to copy a short letter for me—a new Penknife.
IV. My daughter being once quite ready in time to go to Church—a pair of Gloves.
V. Having thought I often desired my Niece to go up stairs for me in the Christmas Week—an Almanack with the new Country Dances in it.
VI. A Present to all my Children on their Mother's Birth-day.
VII. Putting my Wife in good humour when I had an old friend dined with me, and she said we had drank rather too much —a new Gown.
VIII. Half-a-Crown to my Daughter seeing her give Six-pence to a poor Woman very big with Child.
Same day—gave her a new Fan on her seeming much pleased when I came and sat in her Room, and for sweeping up the hearth, which she knew I liked.
IX. To my Son Henry, after I had read a Copy of my own Verses to him, asking me to read them again, tho' rather long— Gil Blas neatly bound.—
Burgess, Printer Ramsgate.

LG.L: YEARS many, and happy, may good Kitty know;
That her Life, like her Temper, unruffled may flow;
A good Husband, and soon, let us find her:
And may she (that Virtues, like her's may be known,
When her Spirit to Regions of Bliss shall have flown,)
Leave another good Kitty behind her.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RECTOR OF ST. STEPHEN, WALBROOK, 19th August, 1807.

LG.L: WHILE sacred Truths exalt the humblest Fane,
And the good Pastor's Life shall form the Base,
What Beauties will St. Stephen's Dome attain,
Fill'd with that Doctrine, which his Virtues grace!
May Heaven its Blessings on the Pastor pour,
Now, and when ruthless Time shall be no more!

DIV1.HEAD: TO MY DEAR SISTER PHIPPS, ON HER BIRTH-DAY, August 20, 1807.

LG.L: MAY firmest Health, with finest Spirits,
And every Good she justly merits,
This Day our Sister greet;
Long may her noble, feeling Heart,
Know all the Joy, she can impart,
And Sorrow never meet.
SOME honest Fellows, who, with lively parts,
Knowing no care, were all above controul,
Sought to expand, in glee, their merry hearts,
And, still with reason, have the flow of soul;
Where shall we meet? exclaim'd each bonny Lad,
Where shall we all our wit and fun disclose,
Choosing, as President, our jolly Dad?
Joy, looking up, cried out "The Ramsgate Rose."
No sooner said than done; each takes his seat
Where Friendship ever will the spot adorn,
And Joke and Fizgig, or some quaint conceit,
Prove "The Rose flourishes without a Thorn."

DIV1.HEAD: LYDIA AND MARIA, On leaving RAMSGATE, September 4, 1807.

LG.L: ADIEU to the Ramsgate delights!
Adieu to the walks on the Pier;
Farewell happy days and sweet nights,
Oh may we renew them next year!
There Mama, and that good Mr. TOWNLEY,
Were so full of their stories and fun,
Which they both could embellish so roundly,
And, one ending, the other begun.
But how wonderful clever's our Aunt;
She can build, she can paint, she can work;
What is there to do that she can't?
And at cards she can play well, and smirk.
Oh the sweet notes of Charles with his Flute,
So clear and yet never too sharp,
Which Henry's Cremona could suit,
Kitty's Voice, or dear Caroline's Harp.

DIV1.P: Burgess, Printer, Ramsgate.

LG.L: Now cease, ye kind Damsels, to praise,
It was you who approach'd to perfection;
Your graceful and good-humour'd ways
Had all that, with good, has connexion;
In truth, as you felt what you say,
The Harmony then was your own;
Your minds were so cheerful and gay,
No other than joy could be known.
But let us describe, if we can,
How you swept the full notes of the Lyre,
Which with Lydian sweet measures began,
And which Sisters' Harmonies inspire.
With tempers and conduct so good,
Any troubles or cares can be eas'd;
And the Party, it's well understood,
Left WHITTON, resolv'd to be pleas'd.
A NOBLE Lord, LORD HERBERT STUART. of noble Spirit,
Of solid Sense, great Taste and Merit,
Once, to a pleasant honest Fellow,
Who likes his Glass, tho' seldom mellow,
Said, with good-natur'd hearty Laughs,
He'd have a Batch with him at Draughts;
Meaning, of course, by way of Fun,
The Bottle, and to him a Pun—
At Dinner then they took their Glass,
Fill'd to a Friend or lovely Lass,
But they were moderate at the Table,
And neither drank as much as able;
For greater Feats they must fulfil,
And, at the Chequers, try their Skill—
My Lord must beat his Friend quite hollow,
'Twas PINDAR striving with APOLLO,
'Twas TOWNLEY coping with LORD HERBERT,
A Shrimp, or Minnow, to a Turbot:
But still 'twas nobly he contended,
And, with four Games, the Contest ended;
The larger Hero, it is true,
Was beat, himself, both black and blue;
That I deny, for thus it finish'd,
My Lord's own Men were just diminish'd,
When 'twas agreed to turn the Table,
To see if Townley now was able
To gain, by Skill or Chance, the Day—
He did it, merrily and gay,
Changing his King and twelve white Men,
For six poor Blackies,—and what then?—
He beat Apollo, that same Night,
Not Black and Blue, but BLACK and WHITE.

DIV1.HEAD: To JAMES BROOKS, Esq With an IRON CHEST.

LG.L: LET me a worthy Friend invest,
With what? an empty Iron Chest,
His honest Gains and wealth to prove;
It would demand a larger Coffer
To hold the Proofs which we could offer,
Of all his Acts of friendly Love.
But you will tell me, plainly dealing,
My Iron Chest and Man of feeling,
Are not of Kin to one another;
I grant it, and this truth impart,
His open, generous, feeling Heart
Calls not Old IRONSIDES a Brother.

DIV1.HEAD: TO MY DEAR SISTER PHIPPS, With a Present of KNIVES and FORKS.

LG.L: WHERE oft' I play a Knife and Fork,
And draw as oft' the willing Cork,
Some recompence is due;
Let me a cheerful Muse invoke,
To temper well a cutting Joke,
I wish to have with you:
My Hostess must accept two Cases
Of Knives and Forks, snug in their Places;
Attended by a Carver;
She'll use the sharp and well wrought Steel
On Beef and Mutton, and on Veal,—
'Twould be a Sin to starve her.
Nay I'll assist to wear them out,
I'll slice the Goose or Turkey Pout,
When thus her Tables laid;
And when the Donor hence is fled,
With Truth, perhaps, it may be said
"He was a merry Blade."
DEAR Kate, or dear Cath'rine, Kitt, Kitty or Kitten,
No matter which way your good Name shall be written,
For though you are call'd by the plain Name of Kate,
Your Temper's the same whether early or late;—
Petruchio himself might stile you good Cattern,
Since for Wives, 'tis confess'd, that you are the best Pattern:
Your Heart and good Humour, Sense, Spirit and Wit,
Will make us rejoice at the dear Name of Kit;
To sing forth your Praises would fill up a Ditty,
And then not describe all the Worth of my Kitty;
Thus dear Kitty or Kate, whether one Name or t'other,
You shall find me your Friend, while you own me your Brother.
I SEND you, dear Jack, some true Pills Analeptic;
They'll do you much good, altho' you're a Sceptic:
To aid their Effects, take a Glass of sound Port,
The Goddess of Health, with good Wine you must court:
Your own Health, â propos, may then be your first Toast,
The next the good Doctor's, of whom much I boast;
Nay a third you may take, all our wishes to crown,
And in Friendship's Old Port you'll best wash the Pills down.
THE Roman Villa, the Italian Sky,
And Nature's Works, with all the Artist's skill,
Delight the Mind, and fill the searching eye,
Yet own the Beauties of our Muswell Hill.
The Forest huge will wave its lofty Head,
The Mountain's Brow o'erhang the lake, or Rill,
The finest fancy by true Genius led,
All, all shall hail our charming Muswell Hill.
And while with Taste true British Hearts are found,
And Love and Loyalty each Breast shall fill,
We'll bless the Land, and that enchanting Ground
Which give such Joys as matchless Muswell Hill.

DIV1.HEAD: ON FOOTE'S DEATH.
DIV1.P: FOOTE having had a Paralytic Stroke, from which he recover∣ed, imitated, shortly afterwards (before a Party with whom he had dined) what, as he conceived, was the Manner in which he appeared when in the Fit; But having in a few Months, another Paralytic Stroke, which proved fatal to him, it occa∣sioned the following Lines.

LG.L: HIS Mimic Art is now no more
To set the Table in a roar,
To lash the Vices of the Age,
Or bring our Follies on the Stage;
For DEATH, who thought the Joke a Scoff,
At length e'en took the Mimic off.—

DIV1.HEAD: TRANSLATION from the CHINESE, On different Chests of Tea. PECOE. SOUCHONG. CONGO. HYSON.

LG.L: FAIR Ladies, if you drink this PECOE,
You'll have a Bloom upon your Cheek-o;
And, if you try my best SOUCHONG,
'Twill add to your bewitching Tongue;
And then your Lover, brave and Strong-o,
Will offer you a dish of CONGO;
But, if my HYSON you will sip,
'Twill give such Sweetness to your Lip,
The Emperor will court your Favour,
And wonder at its charming Flavour.

DIV1.HEAD: THE PICK-POCKET: Impromptu, by JACK KETCH, on a Man's attempting to pick MAJOR SEMPLE's Pocket, in Fleet-Street.

LG.L: HE try'd, but he could not succeed,
To pick the Major's Pocket;—
FILCH ne'er could know the Trade indeed,
To make th'Attempt on LOCKIT.

LG.HEAD: To JACK KETCH.
LG.L: You say that FILCH must try in vain
To make th'Attempt on LOCKIT;—
The reason, sure, is very plain,
He'd nothing in his Pocket.

DIV1.HEAD: SCIPIO, THE WALKING CANE. A School Exercise.

LG.L: IN ancient Story, we are told,
A noble Roman, blind and old,
Was by his Son, for Years, 'tis said,
Through Rome's full Streets so safely led,
That the good Youth, whom all admire
For such Assistance to his Sire,
With honour did the Name obtain
Of SCIPIO, or the Walking Cane:
Let this example serve to prove
How much esteem'd was filial Love.
If any Muse would now support
An humble Bard, who pays his Court,
Or if, in sweet Poetic Verse,
Apollo would some Strains rehearse,
To lead a Youth, who asks his way,
Nor dares to sing his feeble Lay,
He then could such a Scipio boast,
As of his Theme would make the most,
He then would sing, nor sing in vain,
The Praises of the Walking Cane.—
Oh he would tell how great his Fame,
How much his aid to Physic's name;
In former days the Doctor enter'd
With full dress'd Wig, and 'ere he ventur'd
But to pronounce the Patient's case,
He felt the Pulse, with solemn face,
But to prescribe were all in vain
Till to his Nose, he'd put his Cane;
Such Virtues from its head he drew,
Its Golden head, the Patient knew
The danger he was in too well,
If long the Doctor chanc'd to smell.
In HOGARTH'S Prints, those moral Pages,
Where nature ev'ry mind engages,
You're sure to see, aye, more than twenty,
Grave Doctors, with their Canes in plenty.
With modern Sons of learned Galen
The formal Cane is not prevailing;
But clear the Patient's Case they see
When they but feel the Golden fee.—
We need not turn to ancient Days
Arcadia's Shepherdess to raise;
To Windsor or to Richmond go,
The Shepherdess you're sure to know,
If for her Scipio you would look,
Now grown a tall and graceful Crook;
In Delia's hand what charms are shown
From taste and beauty all her own!
But such a Scipio is afraid
Lest he be seiz'd by some Old Maid,
Who against Man will rave and rant,
A Shepherdess, and Maiden Aunt.—
But scarce the Muse, in proper Rhyme,
Can tell the Canes of later Time;
To sing in Verse would give her pain,
If she describe each Modern Cane;
The Bamboos, Crab-Sticks, Jemmy Twitches,
The Oaken Towels, Sword-Canes, Switches,
While some huge Clubs point out the drift
Of the once mighty Hickathrift,
Whose powerful Strength, you'll think I joke,
Would rend the vast and knotty Oak,
Which, as a Jemmy, (if he list)
Of modern Beaux, he'd twirl or twist.
From airy Youth to calmer Age,
The Muse perhaps may turn the Page.
If the poor Cripple I support,
Whose feeble Limbs my aid must court,
In form of what is call'd a Crutch,
The Gouty-Man's relief how much
If he can get, within his Clutches,
Two Scipios or a Pair of Crutches!—
But lest my Friends should think I scost,
With one word more, I'll hobble off—
Each Brother, here, who longs for College,
Will try like me for Classic Knowledge,
That Staff, or Scipio, at Command,
As firm as Hercules he'll stand.

DIV1.HEAD: On a QUACK MEDICINE with the NEW DUTY upon it. By DEATH.

LG.L: I SWEAR by my Dart the immaculate Pitt
Has in Justice pursued the right Track,
Like the Game Laws, at last, he my Province has hit
Through th' Apothecary, Doctor or Quack;
The Tax is as wise, and expedient, as just;
Not a Lawyer wou'd find out a flaw;
With a Medicine what Patient his Life wou'd not trust,
When Death kills but according to Law?
"IS that old Strephon in the Dance"?
Cried Damon, "and with Charlotte too!
"Have Age and Gout the smallest Chance
"One half its Mazes to pursue"?
Love, smiling, said "Oh, envious Swain,
"You know not yet fair Charlotte's Power,
"Her Smile can Grief assuage, or Pain,
"And give to Age a sportive Hour:
"You prove it by yourself, indeed,
"And, learn, that her bewitching Tongue,
"Her Form and Grace, which all exceed,
"Make Damon gay, or Strephon young."

DIV1.HEAD: ON THE Death OF A YOUNG LADY, OF KENSINGTON PALACE.

LG.L: OH let me weep! my Soul, indulge thy Grief!
And in her Virtues only find Relief—
Oh! well I knew her Innocence of Mind—
Those gentle Manners, and that Taste refin'd—
Serene, yet cheerful—gay, yet most correct—
Her Temper charm'd—her Judgment gain'd Respect—
Firm was her Friendship—spotless was her Fame—
Assum'd no Talents, yet had fairest Claim:
I had her Love—to her my own was given,
And her pure Spirit now is claim'd by Heaven.

DIV1.HEAD: THE LOST HAT. On a young Lady's losing her HAT from her VEIL.

LG.L: EITHER stolen or stray'd
From the Head of a Maid,
A smart little Hat is now missing—
"But should a kind Swain
"This Hat once regain
"What Reward would he have?"—Echo—"Kissing."
No, no, tho' the Loss
Would make a Maid cross,
And with Grief did SOPHIA assail,
She vow'd she'd turn Nun,
'Ere that should be done;
And took from that Moment the Veil.
WHY is the beauteous blushing Bride,
Plac'd on the Bridegroom's left-hand Side,
When to the Altar she is led?—
—To indicate his lordly Sway;
The upper hand, to say "Obey"
"I'll knock you down or break your Head."
WITHIN this Grave there is interr'd
That little lying Youth,
Jack Smith, Who never spake a Word
That had a Grain of Truth.—
Jack is consistent, tho' he dies,
For after Death, still here he lies.
WITHIN this Grave, there is interr'd
That little lying Fellow,
Jack, who of Truth ne'er spake a Word
When sober, drunk or mellow:
Jack's now a Paradox, forsooth,
For here he's dead, and lies in Truth.
WHEN FANNY FROLIC was a Wife,
Her first Child came at Seven;
But, when a Widow, odds my life,
Her last was at Eleven.
'TWAS Fanny's Joy to be a Wife,
That hasten'd matters so;
Which were, to lead a widow'd Life,
Retarded by her Woe.

DIV1.HEAD: THE HARE. TO MY BROTHER GEORGE.

LG.L: A PRIOR pledge to take my Dinner
With Doctors and a chosen party
(The fact indeed makes you the Winner)
Or of the Hare I'd eat most hearty.
Puss for a Trio, it is true,
With Pudding might make full amends;
But try what you and Pat can do,
Nor seek "the Hare and many Friends."
WERE Phoebus call'd to strike the Lyre,
What Subject would the God inspire,
And fully prove his power divine?—
The lovely Graces cry in haste,
Pointing to Beauty, Love, and Tate,
"We all proclaim Sweet Caroline".
Can I then dare attempt a Lay
On what demands the God of Day,
Where all the Graces too combine!
While Merit, from her earliest Youth,
With chearful Modesty and Truth
Are proud to own sweet Caroline.
But tho' too feeble be my Verse
Her choicest Virtues to rehearse,
A Wreath of Flowers I will entwine;
For in the Duties of her Life,
As Daughter, Sister, Friend and Wife,
Resplendent shines sweet Caroline.
LIFE, if with credit you'd go through,
These things, at least, there are to do.
Write a book with good ideas;
Build a house to last for years;
Take unto yourself a wife;
Run the risk, altho' for life;
May she be of temper mild!
And, in time, present a child;
Love her; she'll your children nourish;
The olive, thus, and branches flourish.—
Plant trees; grow some along the river's side;
Like the calm current, let life gently glide.—
Paint a picture, quite divinely;
Play the flute or fiddle finely;
Dance a waltz, or hornpipe-gig;
Drive a tandem, or a gig;
Hunt and shoot and course and fish;
Drink your bottle, more don't wish;
Roar a catch, or sing a song;
Tell a pleasant tale, not long;
Smart things say to pretty ladies;
Be Lothario in your gay-days.
MORE MAXIMS â la Par, in verse under par.
Fear the Lord, and keep his laws;
Fight your King and Country's Cause;
Be not proud to poor relations;
Kindly aid them in their stations:
Never borrow; seldom lend;
Make no profligate your friend;
Be not greedy after pelf;
Serve your neighbour; first yourself;
Be of physic ever sparing;
And of law be most forbearing;
Build—and your purse will want repairing.
Never boast your Greek or Latin;
Let your stories come quite pat-in;
Have no tittle tattle talk;
In the path of honour walk.—
No more Maxims I'll be teaching;
Practice better is than preaching.
